utterances: Different tournament this time?
It sure is, and the timing itself is different.
It's in September.
The 1999 tournament you refer to was in June and July, a very quiet time on the international sports calendar.
And therefore it got tons of attention.
Exactly.
And it's - other than Wimbledon, nothing's going on.
The U.S.
women were on the cover of Time, Newsweek, People and Sports Illustrated.
No story has ever done that.
That's how big a deal it was in the U.S.
and record audience nationwide, and worldwide.
So why would you move it to September?
Well, that's a good question.
FIFA, the international governing body, says that the future of its sport is feminine.
That is a quote from about 10 years ago.
And yet they've done the absolute curious thing of having a template for incredible success, the most successful women's-only sporting event ever held on the planet in 1999.
So what do you?
You move it to September, where you're baring it not only in the U.S.
against baseball and college and pro football but around the world.
All the men's soccer league have started up.
So all you can - just scratch your head and say, you know, what are you doing?
And they say, well, you know, China wanted it.
It's better weather.
Well, the Olympics will be in August in China, not September.
So you could have it in August - again, summertime - where it would be a little easier for the women to compete for the newspaper attention, the TV attention.
But you also can't get away from the fact that I think FIFA is probably that last great bastion of male supremacy.
We used to think that of the NFL, but FIFA makes the NFL, I think, look like a NOW convention.
Well, let me - National Organization for Women.
Let me ask, though, if the statement, whether they are following it sincerely or not, if the statement is right.
Is the future of soccer women's soccer?
I think what they mean there, Steve, is that they're maxing out on the men.
I mean, it is the worldwide game and men play it at incredible levels.
So if you want to look at the growth industry of your sport, you would think it would be the women.
But then you would also think you would it at a time where it would get maximum attention.
And instead of that they're burying it; frankly, if the men's World Cup where held in September in the United States, it would fail miserably.
Well, now let's talk about this term that is being held.
Mm-hmm.
Once the baby was born, they would have to, by law, cover the baby.
So they would not give them health insurance until the day the baby was born.
And then they covered the baby in the hospital, but they didn't cover the mother in the hospital.
So that was really shocking.
The group operating the phone bank, Organizing for America, used to be Obama for America during the presidential campaign.
Now it's part of the Democratic National Committee.
The DNC says this is the first big national policy effort since Obama took office.
Eight organizers have been sent to Texas alone.
The Republican National Committee is also taking a grassroots campaign nationwide.
Its spreading a million dollars around the country to oppose the Democrats.
Both parties expect this grassroots push will make a difference.
Southern Methodist University Political Science Professor Cal Jillson says organization will be key.
What we'll see over the next month is how well organized they are, how many people they can get out to town meetings to talk to the Congressmen one way other the other on this matter.
Jillson says Obamas supporters have been here before.
Their network of several million helped elect him.
But he says shell-shocked Republicans are also geared up for their first big fight against the Obama administration.
For NPR News, Im Bill Zeeble in Dallas.
One milestone in black history was commemorated this past weekend by motorcyclists.
Two hundred members of the Buffalo Soldiers Motorcycle Club retraced the 1965 voting rights trail.
That's where Martin Luther King led thousands of civil rights activists from Selma to Montgomery, Alabama.
For weeks, they were turned back or attacked by police.
Finally, they made it to the steps of the state Capitol in Montgomery where Reverend King spoke.
Reverend MARTIN LUTHER KING, JR.: I come to say to you this afternoon, however difficult the moment.
Yes, sir.
However frustrating the hour, will not be long because truth pressed to earth will rise again.
Yes, sir.
How long?
Not long.
Yes, sir.
Because no lie can live forever.
Yes, sir.
How long?
Not long.
(Soundbite of crowd)
Because you shall reap what you sow.
It wasn't long.
Less than five months later, President Lyndon Johnson signed a Voting Rights Act of 1965.
This is Morning Edition from NPR News.
I'm Renee Montagne.
In the months leading up to the election, pollsters focused on several key groups including Hispanics and the young.
Despite a very visible online presence, experts wondered whether young voters would show up in real life.
We'll hear about the youth vote in a moment.
First, we'll explore a notion many posters had before the election that Latinos would not vote for an African-American president.
Luis Clemens is a journalist who covers Hispanic politics and said Tuesday's results dispelled that theory.
Well, that notion has been put to rest, crushed, defeated, obliterated, gone.
Clearly, Hillary Clinton enjoyed enormous, outrageous support among Latino voters.
That support almost entirely shifted in (unintelligible) to Barack Obama once he became the candidate.
What trends in fact did emerge in terms of the Latino vote in different states?
Well, it's interesting.
If you look at Florida, you have a complete reversal of the 56 percent of support of Latinos who supported President Bush in 2004.
This time around it was 57 percent who supported Obama and that sort of shift was emblematic of what happened really across the country.
If you look at state like Nevada, you have a sharp increase in turnout and really a dramatic level of support for the Democratic candidate.
The Democrats are likely to continue the count on a majority of Latino support for a long time to come but at this point, they are on a roll with Latino voters.
What at this point can Republicans do to capture more of that vote at whatever point they can manage it?
Well, I think, Republicans could do a great deal just to change the tenor of the discussion, the tone of the discussion surrounding immigration reform.
Senator McCain very graciously insisted during his concession speech that he wanted to work with the president-elect.
One area where he has been strong at has been immigration reform and one promise that President-elect Obama made was to tackle that issue.

So promises have been made repeatedly to Latino voters and if the two were to really work across the aisle and work on an immigration reform proposal that can pass Congress, it would go a long way towards repairing some of that damage that has taken place over the last few years.
Immigration ended up not being such a big issue in this election, in fact, almost not talked about at all.
Guess what, there's really not that dramatic difference between Obama and McCain on their immigration stands.

I think, Latino voters were able to focus on bread and butter issues, namely Hispanic unemployment going up as a result of this economic crisis and quite clearly, widespread concern among all groups about the economy, but I think particularly so among the Latinos and that is what drives the shift from George Bush to Barack Obama in four years.
Luis Clemens is a political analyst and a journalist specializing in Hispanic politics.
Thanks very much for joining us.
Happy to be here.
When Jacob Lew finished his first tour as White House budget director in 2001, he left behind a budget surplus of $237 billion.
Now President Obama has nominated Lew to take a second swipe at the job and the circumstances could scarcely be more different.
Lew will face a budget deficit of some $1.3 trillion, and decisions that will be difficult to say the least.
NPR's Brian Naylor reports.
President Obama had high praise for 54-year-old Jacob Jack Lew, as he announced his choice for director of the Office of Management and Budget at the White House yesterday.
First strike, first edition, first place.
Good.
Imagine enough water to fill two of the Great Lakes, sitting underground below some of the driest parts of eight states.
That was the High Plains Aquifer 60 years ago.
Since then, new pumping and irrigation systems have made it easy for farmers to extract billions of gallons of water and use it to grow lucrative crops.
An agricultural gold rush of sorts followed, transforming the regional economy.
Well, now parts of the aquifer are drying out, as we hear from Frank Morris of member station KCUR.
(SOUNDBITE OF VEHICLE)
Nate Pike has been riding the dry rolling ranch lands south of Dodge City, Kansas for most of his 80 years, sometimes just to visit a spring called St. Jacob's Well.
As a young boy, I'd saddle me a horse, put me a little cane pole on it and come down here and fish.
